awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Controlling Biomolecular Structure and Function at Surfaces and Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
With this new award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A Program (CSDM-A) and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program (CLP) of the Division of Chemistry support Professor Lauren Webb of the University of Texas at Austin in a project that will investigate new methods for attaching proteins to surfaces under conditions that allow the protein activity to be studied. These studies, which will allow construction of surfaces with functional proteins attached, will have applications in material science and biomedical engineering. This project, which combines biophysics, molecular biology with surface and materials chemistry, will provide multidisciplinary training to students, from undergraduates to post-doctorals, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.

Prof. Webb and her group are conducting a multi-pronged effort with the aim of developing surfaces that mimic stable and functional biological materials capable of both natural and artificial functions.  Specific experiments that are being conducted include: (1) the further work on the chemical functionalization of alkane thiol surfaces with peptides, with engineered secondary structure; (2) the binding of more complex protiens to the protein surfaces created in (1); (3) the use of surface functionalization developed in (1) to drive the formation of protein aggregates on the surface; (4) the use of protein-functionalized surfaces to bind functional forms of enzymes to the surface and to measure their activity.  Students working with Prof. Webb are obtaining significant experience in analytical, physical and biochemical methods.  This interdisciplinary training prepares them for work in the technical workforce.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The goal of this project was to functionalize gold surfaces with biological molecules capable of both natural and artificial (designed) functions.  The success of the long-term goals of this project will enable folded and functional proteins to be integrated into traditional inorganic materials in order to incorporate their biological function into an artificial device. This project used a multidisciplinary approach for fabricating novel biomimetic materials at the so-called “bio/abio interface” in a comprehensive experimental and theoretical approach.  Our project goals were enabled by a surface chemical functionalization strategy previously demonstrated in our laboratory, shown in Figure 1.  In this strategy, mixed monolayers of alkane thiols, some terminated in a reactive azide (N3) group, form a self-assembled monolayer (SAM) on a flat gold surface.  The azide groups are then exposed to peptides containing multiple triple bonds, and under appropriate conditions, react through a Huisgen cycloaddition (“click chemistry”) to chemically bond the peptide to the surface in multiple locations.

There are four major results from this work.

1) We have expanded the complexity of our surfaces by adding chemical diversity to all aspects of our substrate and surface-bound biomolecule. This expands the capability of this surface chemistry for a variety of applications, both in our laboratory and for other researchers.

2) We have demonstrated the controlled nucleation and growth of functional peptide-based fibrils on functionalized gold surfaces. We are now using this strategy to study the mechanism of fibril formation and growth in a controlled way. We believe this work will inform both the study of biologically active fibrils and in materials science applications.

3) We have developed accurate computational strategies for predicting peptide structures at surfaces. This will enable us to understand mechanisms of how surfaces affect biomolecular structure and the resulting function at the molecular level.

4) Finally, using neutron reflectometry (NR) at the Spallation Neutron Source (SNS) at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), we have demonstrated that standard well-formed SAMs contain large amounts of water, probably at grain boundaries and other imperfections in the surface.  This is vital information for the large community of researchers who use SAMs in their experiments. 

At all points, we have sought to characterize our surfaces in significant detail in order to reliably replicate and modify previous successes, often a weakness in studies of surface-bound peptides and proteins.  This work has resulted in four publications, one additional manuscript in preparation, and we anticipate at least one further publication acknowledging this NSF support.

Broader Impacts:  The primary goal of the Broader Impacts of this project was to develop, administer, analyze, and report the results of a comprehensive, longitudinal survey of the quality of life of graduate students in the Department of Chemistry at UT-Austin. The goal of this ambitious and long-term project is to improve the graduate training and mentoring program at UT-Austin through quantitative assessment of data on all aspects of the factors that influence our graduate students’ progress through their degree program, career goals, and career development. Over the first year of this project, a small group of volunteer graduate students worked carefully with PI Webb to construct a high quality survey instrument; this survey was given to graduate students in the Department of Chemistry in May 2015.  The survey consisted of sections involving: 1. Financial Management; 2. Resource Awareness; 3. Career Goals; 4. Research Environment; 5. Personal/Family Life; 6. Departmental Climate; 7. Qualifying for Doctoral Candidacy; 8. Teaching; and 9. Overall Satisfaction, including a free response section. The response rate was 59%, considered exceptional in the survey research field. The survey was again given in spring 2017, and a report on these results is now being prepared for dissemination.  This survey provides the opportunity to improve the graduate program in this department through quantitative feedback from our graduate students, so that we can make meaningful changes to our graduate training program that actually aid and help our students.


Last Modified: 11/21/2017
Modified by: Lauren Webb

Image
  • Surface functionalization scheme. Left: A mixed monolayer of alkane thiols with and without a terminal bromine. Middle: This is reacted with NaN3, resulting in a N3-terminated surface. Right: This is exposed to a synthetic peptide carrying two triple bonds: top: (KKLL)x; bottom: peptide (KL)x.
    Lauren Webb
    Copyrighted
    Lauren Webb
    Figure 1
